Official corruption is rampant in Thailand.<ref name=HRR-2016>{{cite web|title=Country Reports on Human Rights Practices for 2016; Thailand|url=https://www.state.gov/j/drl/rls/hrrpt/humanrightsreport/index.htm?year=2016&dlid=265376|website=US Department of State|accessdate=4 March 2017}}</ref><ref name=BACP>{{cite web|title=Business Anti-Corruption Portal: Thailand |url=http://www.business-anti-corruption.com/country-profiles/east-asia-the-pacific/thailand/show-all.aspx|publisher=GAN Integrity Solutions|website=Business Anti-Corruption Portal|accessdate=2 July 2015}}</ref> It ranges from bribery to outright police collusion. The interplay of drugs, [[Prostitution in Thailand|prostitution]], political paralysis, corruption and collusion, a culture of impunity,<ref name="thaiprisonlife"/> international tourism and trade, traditional Buddhist tolerance<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thaiprisonlife.com/news/death-penalty-abolished-for-young-offenders/ |title=Death penalty abolished for young offenders | Thai Prison Life – ชีวิตในเรือนจำ |publisher=Thaiprisonlife.com |date=2012-08-30 |accessdate=2014-04-12}}</ref> and tendency to ignore problems has led to an increasingly multifaceted and complex crime epidemic in the country. [[Juvenile delinquency]] has also been increasing in recent years.<ref>{{cite journal|title= Intergenerational transmission of religious beliefs and practices and the reduction of adolescent delinquency in urban Thailand|date=2014-01-24 |pmid=23218782 | doi=10.1016/j.adolescence.2012.09.011 |volume=36 |pmc=3543117 |journal=J Adolesc |pages=79–89 | last1 = Chamratrithirong | first1 = A | last2 = Miller | first2 = BA | last3 = Byrnes | first3 = HF | last4 = Rhucharoenpornpanich | first4 = O | last5 = Cupp | first5 = PK | last6 = Rosati | first6 = MJ | last7 = Fongkaew | first7 = W | last8 = Atwood | first8 = KA | last9 = Todd | first9 = M}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=Takaaki Nishiyama |url=http://ajw.asahi.com/article/asia/south_east_asia/AJ201310120010 |title=For Thailand, learning the Japanese way of reforming delinquents pays dividends - AJW by The Asahi Shimbun |publisher=Ajw.asahi.com |date= |accessdate=2014-04-12 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140222002755/https://ajw.asahi.com/article/asia/south_east_asia/AJ201310120010 |archivedate=2014-02-22 |df= }}</ref>
In November 2015, the ''New York Times'' reported that in the fiscal year ending September 2015, the national police have seen a surge in thefts, burglaries, and robberies, more than 75,557 thefts and other property crimes in the fiscal year, 10.5 percent higher than the previous year. Violent crime was up 8.6 percent during the same period.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Fuller|first1=Thomas|title=Thai Economy and Spirits Are Sagging|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/11/30/world/asia/thailand-economy-tourism.html?_r=0|accessdate=30 November 2015|work=New York Times|date=2015-11-29}}</ref> These figures have been contested by the police and by Amorn Wanichwiwatana, a criminologist at [[Chulalongkorn University]], who said he was not aware of any significant uptick in crime since the military came to power. "I don’t think that’s the case. It's not possible," he said of the 60 percent increase reported by the ''Times''. Crime statistics from the Royal Thai Police (RTP) show a statistically negligible increase of 1.9 percent over the same period, with 920 additional crimes reported after an overall decline since 2009.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Charuvastra |first1=Teeranai |last2=Ruiz |first2=Todd |title=Data Contradicts New York Times on Crime Increase Under Junta |url=http://www.khaosodenglish.com/detail.php?newsid=1449660405&section=12 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160204025913/http://www.khaosodenglish.com/detail.php?%C3%A5newsid=1449660405&section=12# |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2016-02-04 |accessdate=9 December 2015 |work=Khaosod English |date=2015-12-09 |df= }}</ref>
Augmenting the crime prevention efforts of the RTP, there are an estimated 3,000-4,000 security companies in Thailand, deploying between 400,000-500,000 security guards nationwide.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Sukyingcharoenwong|first1=Mayuree|title=Security guards, firms fret over cost from new law|url=http://www.nationmultimedia.com/news/national/30307966|accessdate=18 March 2017|work=Sunday Nation|date=5 March 2017|page=2|format=Print edition only}}</ref>
==By location== Much of Thailand's crime is in urban areas where tourists congregate as they are easy targets, as well as where rampant [[Prostitution in Thailand|prostitution]] and human trafficking feeds their vices. The prime areas of drug abuse are [[Bangkok]], [[Phuket Province|Phuket]], and [[Pattaya]], but not limited to these areas. The prime transit corridor for drugs entering northern Thailand is from the [[Golden Triangle (Southeast Asia)|Golden Triangle]], as well as from ethnically divided rebel-controlled areas within the fragmented state of [[Myanmar]], especially [[Shan State]]. Thailand's international ports, like [[Laem Chabang]] near Pattaya, and [[Suvarnabhumi International Airport]], have seen a number of African<ref>{{cite news|last1=Ngamkham|first1=Wassayos|title=Love, marriage and drug mules: Thai women are being tricked into drug trafficking|url=http://www.bangkokpost.com/learning/learning-from-news/221542/african-drug-gangs-target-thai-women|accessdate=2015-01-24|work=Bangkok Post|date=2011-02-14}}</ref> and former [[Commonwealth of Independent States]] gangs, as well as other transnational gangs and [[drug mules]] involved in the trade.
== Crime by type ==
===Drugs and druggings=== Thailand has a growing problem of drugs and the violence associated with it.<ref name=globalpost>{{cite news|last1=Winn|first1=Patrick|title=Thailand: monks on meth|url=http://www.globalpost.com/globalpost-blogs/southeast-asia/monks-methamphetamine|accessdate=7 Mar 2015|work=globalpost|date=2012-10-18}}</ref> The drugs involved range from the traditional, [[kratom]],<ref name="nytimes">https://www.nytimes.com/2012/07/23/world/asia/kratom-leaf-for-drug-cocktail-adds-to-thailands-woes.html?pagewanted=all</ref> to [[ya ba]], opium from [[Myanmar]], and local herbal medicines.<ref name="nytimes"/>
A previous attempt to control the drug trade by declaring the [[Human rights in Thailand#Deaths relating to the 2003 war on drugs|2003 War on Drugs]], was met with allegations of [[Thaksin Shinawatra|Thaksin]]-allied, politically-inspired targeted killings, quotas of dead drug traffickers, and the targeting of innocent victims.{{Citation needed|date=March 2015}}
Methampetamines are so widely abused that animals, such as [[gibbons]], slow [[loris]]es,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://thethaiger.com/news/phuket/Phuket-wildlife-officers-warn-Bangla-slow-loris-raids-come |title=Phuket wildlife officers warn of Bangla slow loris raids to come |work=Phuket Gazette |date=2014-03-20 |accessdate=2018-09-29 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121019192500/http://www.phuketgazette.net/phuket_news/2012/Phuket-wildlife-officers-warn-of-Bangla-slow-loris-raids-to-come-19199.html |archivedate=October 19, 2012 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.pattayaone.net/pattaya-news/51010/police-arrest-slow-loris-owners-south-pattaya/ |title=Police arrest Slow Loris owners in South Pattaya |work=Pattaya One |date=2012-03-15 |accessdate=2014-04-12 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140413131212/http://www.pattayaone.net/pattaya-news/51010/police-arrest-slow-loris-owners-south-pattaya/# |archive-date=2014-04-13 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref> and elephants<ref name="asiasentinel">{{cite web|url=http://www.asiasentinel.com/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=4475&Itemid=392 |title=Massive Drug Smuggling in Thailand |work=Asia Sentinel |date=2012-05-04 |accessdate=2014-04-12 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130821100443/http://asiasentinel.com/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=4475&Itemid=392 |archivedate=August 21, 2013 |df= }}</ref> are force-fed stimulants to make them work longer hours, sedated to allow petting and entertain [[Tourism in Thailand|tourists]].{{Citation needed|date=March 2015}}
In May 2012, it was discovered that nearly 50 million legal [[pseudoephedrine]] tablets had been stolen from Thai hospitals.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Ehrlich|first1=Richard|title=Illegal Methamphetamines Made From Drugs in Thai Hospitals are Stolen|url=http://www.scoop.co.nz/stories/WO1205/S00516/illegal-methamphetamines-made-from-drugs-in-thai-hospitals.htm|accessdate=23 May 2012|work=Scoop World|date=2012-05-23}}</ref> Two billion more tablets were smuggled in from [[Taiwan]] and [[South Korea]], with forged documents showing two Thai companies importing some eight billion more.<ref name="asiasentinel"/> They had reported the drugs to be imports of electronics and automobile parts. Thailand responded by close monitoring of the sale and distribution of pseudoephedrine.<ref>{{cite news|title=Rehabilitation in Thailand|url=https://rehabs.asia/thailand/|work=Rhabs Asia|date=2016-09-15}}</ref>
Druggings of tourists and locals alike by sex workers and thieves are an infrequent, but not uncommon, occurrence in major tourist centers like Pattaya or Phuket.<ref>{{cite news|title=Women drug, rob foreigners|url=http://www.bangkokpost.com/print/478518/|accessdate=11 November 2016|work=Bangkok Post|date=2015-02-08}}</ref>
A United Nations report on the situation in Thailand states, "Many of those now incarcerated in Thailand's prisons are likely to be low-level traders and drug users, as they are more easy targets for police, rather than large scale traffickers and organised criminals".<ref>[https://www.tni.org/en/weblog/item/3889-amidst-deep-concern-for-thailands-drug-policies-some-space-for-open-debate Amidst deep concern for Thailand's drug policies, some space for open debate] Transnational Institute, 2012</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Winn|first1=Patrick|title=Thailand is moving closer to decriminalizing meth|url=http://www.pri.org/stories/2016-09-07/thailand-moving-closer-decriminalizing-meth|accessdate=30 October 2016|publisher=Public Radio International (PRI)|date=8 September 2016}}</ref>
===Animal abuse=== {{See|Animal welfare in Thailand}}
Animal abuse in Thailand is widespread, including elephants tortured for tourism,<ref>{{cite news|last1=Campbell|first1=Charlie|title=Elephants Are Tortured and Trafficked to Entertain Tourists in Thailand|url=http://time.com/2965190/burma-myanmar-thailand-elephants-trafficked-tortured-tourism/|accessdate=6 Mar 2015|work=Time|date=2014-07-08}}</ref> killing elephants for their tusks,<ref>{{cite news|title=Thailand accused of fueling ivory trade|url=http://www.bangkokpost.com/news/local/418534/thai-elephant-population-too-small-to-supply-huge-local-ivory-market|accessdate=6 Mar 2015|work=Bangkok Post|date=2014-07-02}}</ref> smuggling them from [[Myanmar]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.worldbulletin.net/news/140195/thailand-asked-to-combat-rise-in-elephant-smuggling|title=Thailand asked to combat 'rise' in elephant smuggling - Health & Environment - Worldbulletin News|work=World Bulletin}}</ref> exploiting elephants in cities,<ref>{{cite news|last1=Fuller|first1=Thomas|title=In Bangkok, it's a tough life for elephants|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/01/13/world/asia/13iht-elephants.1.9172548.html?pagewanted=all&_r=0|accessdate=6 Mar 2015|work=New York Times|date=2008-01-13}}</ref> and trading in animal parts.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Pakkawan|first1=Assawin|title=Tiger parts found on highway|url=http://www.bangkokpost.com/news/local/419538/tiger-parts-found-on-highway|accessdate=6 Mar 2015|work=Bangkok Post|date=2014-07-08}}</ref>
===Rape=== In 2013, some 87 women came forward daily to report sexual abuse or to seek counseling as a result of sexual abuse in Thailand, with most offenders known to the victim. Police refused to accept many complaints, giving excuses such as "political unrest". The youngest victim was aged one year and nine months and eldest was 85. The youngest offender was a 10-year-old boy who took part in a gang-rape and the eldest was an 85-year-old man who molested a young girl.<ref>{{cite news|title=About 80 sex-abuse cases reported daily in Thailand |url=http://www.asianewsnet.net/news-58300.html |accessdate=6 Mar 2015 |work=The Nation |publisher=Asia News Network |date=2014-03-21 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141113044431/http://www.asianewsnet.net/news-58300.html |archivedate=November 13, 2014 |df= }}</ref>
===Fraud=== Thailand as a major tourist destination is infamous for scams and touts. Among the most famous and lucrative are the [[gem scam]], [[Thai tailor scam]], and fake travel agents<ref>{{cite news|title=Cheap Japan-Korea Tours Too Good To Be True |url=http://www.pattayadailynews.com:80/en/2012/10/26/cheap-japan-korea-tours-too-good-to-be-true/ |accessdate=8 August 2016 |work=Pattaya Daily News |date=26 October 2012 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121030083414/http://www.pattayadailynews.com/en/2012/10/26/cheap-japan-korea-tours-too-good-to-be-true/ |archivedate=30 October 2012 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thisisderbyshire.co.uk/Crook-4-5-million-scam-ordered-pay-66-000/story-15727504-detail/story.html|title=Crook part of £4.5 million scam ordered to pay back £66,000|work=Derby Telegraph|access-date=2012-11-18|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120407214807/http://www.thisisderbyshire.co.uk/Crook-4-5-million-scam-ordered-pay-66-000/story-15727504-detail/story.html#|archive-date=2012-04-07|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref> and [[Thai zig zag scam]].
The [[Boiler room (business)|boiler room]] scam (a fake stock trading scam) is perhaps the most publicized white collar crime in Thailand.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Farrell |first1=James Austin |title=The Boiler Room Boys |url=http://www.chiangmainews.com/ecmn/viewfa.php?id=3120 |accessdate=6 Mar 2015 |work=Citylife Chiang Mai |issue=Vol. 20 No. 3 |date=Mar 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140322052000/http://www.chiangmainews.com/ecmn/viewfa.php?id=3120 |archivedate=March 22, 2014 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.couchsurfing.org/group_read.html?gid=418&post=12469202 |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130414152526/http://www.couchsurfing.org/group_read.html?gid=418&post=12469202 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2013-04-14 |title=Thailand |publisher=Couchsurfing |date= |accessdate=2014-04-12 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Lowe |first=Greg |url=http://travel.cnn.com/bangkok/life/tell-me-about-it/greg-lowe-how-deal-bangkoks-illegal-financial-advisors-926050 |title=Greg Lowe: How to deal with Bangkok's illegal financial advisors|website=Travel.cnn.com |date=2011-04-12 |accessdate=2014-04-12}}</ref><ref>https://www.nytimes.com/2011/06/11/world/asia/11taiwan.html{{failed verification|date=November 2018}}</ref>
[[Stateless person]]s are targeted with fake [[UN]] working rights cards.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.bangkokpost.com/news/investigation/321826/cards-stacked-against-migrants-sucked-into-scam |title=Cards stacked against migrants sucked into scam|work=Bangkok Post |date=2012-11-18 |accessdate=2014-04-12}}</ref>
Serious passport and identification forgery caught the attention of US authorities after the disappearance of [[Malaysia Airlines Flight 370]]. Some 259 stolen visa labels had disappeared from a Thai consulate in Malaysia in August 2013.<ref>http://www.khaosod.co.th/en/view_newsonline.php?newsid=TVRNM056RTRNREV6TlE9PQ== {{webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20140322023413/http://www.khaosod.co.th/en/view_newsonline.php?newsid=TVRNM056RTRNREV6TlE9PQ== |date=2014-03-22 }}{{DL|date=November 2018}}</ref> They were used to cross the Thai border illegally. Thirty-five Iranians, one Cameroonian, 20 Nigerians, four Pakistanis, four Indians, and others from Asia made the crossing.<ref>http://www.khaosod.co.th/en/view_newsonline.php?newsid=TVRNM056RTRNREV6TlE9PQ== {{webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20140322023413/http://www.khaosod.co.th/en/view_newsonline.php?newsid=TVRNM056RTRNREV6TlE9PQ== |date=2014-03-22 }}{{DL|date=November 2018}}</ref>
===Human trafficking and prostitution === {{main|Prostitution in Thailand|Human trafficking in Thailand}}
In 2013, the US State Department stated that Thailand faced the lowest rank (e.g. failing) in its Trafficking In Persons Report.<ref name="reuters.com">{{cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2013/12/05/us-thailand-rohingya-usa-idUSBRE9B401H20131205|title=Thailand's anti-trafficking effort loses steam|work=Reuters}}</ref> The 2013 report stated that Thai police and immigration officials "extorted money or sex" from detainees or "sold Burmese migrants unable to pay labor brokers or sex traffickers,".<ref name="reuters.com"/> According to officials from the [[International Labour Organization]] (ILO), Thailand was the only government to vote against the [[United Nations]] [[Forced Labour Convention]] at the ILO's annual ministerial conference in June 2014.<ref name="trustforced">{{cite web|url=http://www.trust.org/item/20140611164402-hj46x|title=Pact to halt forced labour snubbed by Thailand, Gulf - ILO|author=Thomson Reuters Foundation|work=trust.org}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://allafrica.com/stories/201406121748.html|title=Africa: UN Agency Adopts Treaty Advancing Global Efforts to Tackle Forced Labour|work=allAfrica.com}}</ref>
In response, [[Walmart]] and [[Costco]] retail chains in USA have dumped [[Charoen Pokphand]] as a supplier of seafood products due to suppliers that "own, operate or buy from fishing boats manned with slaves." <ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/money/business/2014/06/10/costco-walmart-slave-labor/10274641/|title=Shrimp slaves: Walmart, Costco act against forced labor|date=10 June 2014|work=USA TODAY}}</ref> The Thai government on 15 June 2014 caved to international pressure and explained its intention to rescind its previous ILO vote.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nationmultimedia.com/national/Thailand-reverses-earlier-decision-backs-ILO-proto-30236260.html|title=Thailand reverses earlier decision, backs ILO protocol on forced labour|date=15 June 2014|work=The Nation}}</ref>
===Domestic violence=== Violence against women and children has been rising in Thailand. In 2006, 13,550 cases of [[domestic violence]] against women and children were reported by Thailand's [[Ministry of Public Health (Thailand)|Ministry of Public Health]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.irinnews.org/report/80513/thailand-fighting-domestic-violence|title=Fighting domestic violence|work=IRIN|date=2008-09-22|accessdate=6 March 2017}}</ref> Between 2007 and 2015 the total number of violence victims seeking assistance at the One-Stop Crisis Centre of the Public Health Ministry totalled 207,891. Of those, 105,622 involved children those involving women amounted to 102,269. In 2016, the number of distressed women and children seeking assistance from the centre was 20,018, according to the [[National Economic and Social Development Board]] (NESDB).<ref>{{cite news|title=Spouses, boyfriends blamed for violence against women and children|url=http://www.nationmultimedia.com/news/breakingnews/30308099|accessdate=6 March 2017|work=The Nation|date=6 March 2017}}</ref>
===Foreign gangs and fugitives=== Thailand has been described as a "haven" for criminals on the run from the law in their homelands.<ref name="ST-20160804">{{cite news|title=Why is Thailand the land of fugitives?: The Nation|url=http://www.straitstimes.com/asia/se-asia/why-is-thailand-the-land-of-fugitives-the-nation|access-date=8 August 2016|work=Straits Times|date=4 August 2016}}</ref> Further, foreign criminal gangs have adopted Thailand as a base of operations. A 2014 study by the Thailand Institute of Justice identified 22 separate gangs of foreigners involved in identity fraud, petty theft, and burglary. Thailand's economic reliance on tourism<ref>{{cite news|last1=Sriring|first1=Orathai|last2=Webb|first2=Simon|title=Tourism, infrastructure to support Thailand's economy this year: BOT Governor|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-thailand-economy-cenbank-idUSKCN10I11W?il=0|access-date=8 August 2016|agency=Reuters|date=7 August 2016}}</ref> means that it is all too easy{{Clarify|reason=vague|date=April 2017}} for foreign criminals to enter the country. Bribery is frequently used to cement friendly relations with local officials, particularly the police. Their palms greased, police and immigration officials ignore wrongdoing.<ref name="ST-20160804" /> "Thailand has traditionally been one of the top source countries for extradition of criminals to the U.S.," said a March 2009 cable from the American Embassy in Bangkok obtained by WikiLeaks.<ref name="NYT-20110720">{{cite news|last1=Fuller|first1=Thomas|title=Fugitives, and Others, in Pursuit of Vice Find Thailand’s Liberties to Be a Virtue|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/07/21/world/asia/21iht-thailand21.html|accessdate=8 August 2016|work=New York Times|date=20 July 2011}}</ref> "There are a number of minor reasons and one very major one why the jet-setting underground would find Thailand irresistible," according to Thailand-based British author Mr. [[John Burdett]]. "The minor ones would include guns, girls, gambling, [[Cannabis (drug)|ganja]] and gorgeous beaches, especially for those recently released from confinement." But, he said, what makes Thailand especially attractive, "is the ...compliant and bribable police force."<ref name="NYT-20110720" />
== Crime dynamics == ===Firearms=== About one in ten people in Thailand legally own a gun. There are more than six million registered guns in a country with a population of 66.7 million.<ref name="DW-20160219">{{cite news |last1=Domínguez |first1=Gabriel |title=A look at Thailand's fervent gun culture |url=https://www.dw.com/en/a-look-at-thailands-fervent-gun-culture/a-19060721 |accessdate=31 October 2018 |work=Deutsche Welle |date=2016-02-19}}</ref> [[Small Arms Survey]] estimates that the total number of guns, both licit and illicit, held by Thai civilians in 2017 is 10,300,000,<ref name="SAS-2018">{{cite book |last1=Karp |first1=Aaron |title=Briefing Paper; Estimating Global Civilian-Held Firearms Numbers |publisher=Small Arms Survey; Graduate Institute of International and Development Studies |location=Geneva |page=4 |edition=June 2018 |url=http://www.smallarmssurvey.org/fileadmin/docs/T-Briefing-Papers/SAS-BP-Civilian-Firearms-Numbers.pdf |accessdate=1 November 2018}}</ref> equating to 15.1 firearms per 100 inhabitants. Comparable figures for the other [[ASEAN]] nations are: Cambodia, 4.5 per 100 inhabitants; Philippines, 3.6; Laos, 3.0; Myanmar, 1.6; Vietnam, 1.6; Brunei, 1.4; Malaysia, 0.7; Singapore, 0.3; and Indonesia, zero.<ref>{{cite web |title=Civilian Firearms Holdings 2017 |url=http://www.smallarmssurvey.org/fileadmin/docs/Weapons_and_Markets/Tools/Firearms_holdings/SAS-BP-Civilian-held-firearms-annexe.pdf |website=Small Arms Survey (SAS) |accessdate=1 November 2018}}</ref>
Ownership of firearms is particularly high in the south Thailand provinces of [[Pattani]], [[Yala Province|Yala]], and [[Narathiwat]] that have witnessed significant [[South Thailand Insurgency|insurgency and rebellion since 2004]].<ref name="DW-20160219" />
In 2016 Thailand's rate of violent gun-related deaths stood at 4.45 deaths per 100,000 inhabitants. In comparison, that of the Philippines was 7.42; the US, 3.85; Cambodia, 0.96; Myanmar, 0.56; Malaysia, 0.46; Indonesia, 0.10; and Singapore, 0.03.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Aizenman |first1=Nurith |title=Gun Violence: How The U.S. Compares With Other Countries |url=https://www.npr.org/sections/goatsandsoda/2017/10/06/555861898/gun-violence-how-the-u-s-compares-to-other-countries |accessdate=1 November 2018 |work=National Public Radio (NPR) |date=October 6, 2017}}</ref>
===School violence and delinquency=== Technical colleges for years have seen rival gang shootings at major intersections in Bangkok and elsewhere, and tends to be an urban phenomenon.<ref>"[http://www.bangkokpost.com/breakingnews/308354/2-students-held-in-fatal-bus-shooting 2 students held in fatal bus shooting]." ''[[Bangkok Post]]''. 19 Aug 2012.</ref> In one famous case, one such shootout began in response to [[Gangnam style]] faceoff.<ref>Boehler, Patrick."[http://newsfeed.time.com/2012/09/24/gangnam-style-dance-off-ends-in-shootout/ 'Gangnam Style' Dance-Off Ends in Shoot-Out]." ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]''. 24 Sep 2012.</ref> One technical school student is quoted as saying, "Guns are like school supplies. On our campus, we might use a gun to protect ourselves from violent, unruly seniors. Outside, we have rival schools..."<ref>{{cite news|last1=Sukpanich|first1=Tunya|title=Easy guns bring Wild West mentality|url=http://www.bangkokpost.com/news/investigation/321825/easy-gun-access-giving-rise-to-a-wild-west-mentality|accessdate=7 Mar 2015|work=Bangkok Post|date=2012-11-18}}</ref>
Juvenile delinquency from 2003 to 2007 exploded, increasing some 70 percent, with both genders reporting large increases, despite the country moving up world economic rankings.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Narkvichetr|first1=Korakod|title=JUVENILE CRIME AND TREATMENT OF SERIOUS AND VIOLENT JUVENILE DELINQUENTS IN THAILAND|publisher=United Nations Asia and Far East Institute for the Prevention of Crime and the Treatment of Offenders|date=n.d.|url=http://www.unafei.or.jp/english/pdf/RS_No78/No78_16PA_Narkvichetr.pdf|accessdate=5 March 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161205231554/http://unafei.or.jp/english/pdf/RS_No78/No78_16PA_Narkvichetr.pdf|archive-date=2016-12-05|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref>
=== Prison infrastructure and corruption === Thailand has woefully inadequate prison infrastructure, as well as a lack of political will to deal with the exploding crime problem.{{Citation needed|date=March 2015}} In [[Rayong Central Prison]], which was designed to house 3,000 inmates but holds 6,000, improvised rocket canisters were used to relay goods from the outside world over the top of walls into the prison.<ref name=thaiprisonlife>{{cite news|title=Overwhelming odds get better of efforts to stamp out prison drug trade|url=http://www.thaiprisonlife.com/news/overwhelming-odds-get-better-of-efforts-to-stamp-out-prison-drug-trade/|accessdate=6 Mar 2015|work=Bangkok Post|publisher=Thai Prison Life|date=2012-09-09}}</ref> Mail sent to prisoners contained items such as mobile phones used to coordinate and organize crime outside of the prison.<ref name="pattayaone">{{cite news|title=Two suspected Pattaya drug dealers arrested and 2,000 Yabba Tablets seized|url=http://www.pattayaone.net/tag/rayong-central-prison/|work=Pattaya One|date=2012-11-03|accessdate=2018-10-31|deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140413131832/http://www.pattayaone.net/tag/rayong-central-prison/ |archivedate=April 13, 2014 |df= }}</ref> This situation is not unique to Rayong Prison, and is commonplace throughout Thailand.<ref name="pdn">{{cite news|work=Pattaya Daily News|title=Inmates at Rayong Central Prison have Assistance with Smuggling Contraband and Drugs|date=2012-04-30|author= Nattaphummint|url=http://www.pattayadailynews.com/en/2012/04/30/inmates-at-rayong-central-prison-have-assistance-with-smuggling-contraband-and-drugs/ |accessdate=18 November 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121108024936/http://www.pattayadailynews.com/en/2012/04/30/inmates-at-rayong-central-prison-have-assistance-with-smuggling-contraband-and-drugs/ |archivedate=November 8, 2012 |df= }}</ref>
Corrupt prison officials add to the issues of dealing with escalating crime.<ref name=pdn /> In one case, a prison nurse was caught dealing drugs.<ref>{{cite web|title=Prison nurse caught selling drugs to inmates|url=http://www.thaiprisonlife.com/news/prison-nurse-caught-selling-drugs-to-inmates/|website=Thai Prison Life|publisher=''Bangkok Post''|accessdate=6 Mar 2015|date=2012-09-24}}</ref> In a sting operation some 28 prison wardens were found to be smuggling drugs.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Laohong|first1=King-Oua|last2=Rakrun|first2=Nucharee|title=Prison officials sacked after contraband blitz|url=http://www.bangkokpost.com/lite/topstories/290814/prison-officials-sacked-after-contraband-blitz|accessdate=6 Mar 2015|work=Bangkok Post|date=2012-04-28}}</ref> Authorities are so corrupt or incompetent that females were found in one male cell feeding five babies.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://pattayadailynews.com/inmates-at-rayong-central-prison-have-assistance-with-smuggling-contraband-and-drugs/|title=Inmates at Rayong Central Prison have Assistance with Smuggling Contraband and Drugs|work=pattayadailynews.com}}</ref> Thai authorities have responded by installing mobile phone jamming equipment, but these jammers has been proven to offer a false sense of security, as a wall crack was used to store phones where the jammers could not penetrate.<ref>{{cite news|title=Search of Khao Bin Prison turns up more illegal objects|url=http://www.thaiprisonlife.com/news/search-of-khao-bin-prison-turns-up-more-illegal-objects/|accessdate=6 Mar 2015|work=The Nation|agency=Thai Prison Life|date=2012-02-11}}</ref> Other initiatives include x-ray scanners,<ref name="thaiprisonlife"/> and installing CCTV equipment. A new super-max prison is in the planning stages.<ref>http://www.bangkokpost.com/learning/learning-from-news/277972/super-maximum-security-prison-planned</ref>
=== Buddhist monks === Crime has infiltrated all components of Thai society, including Buddhist institutions. The monastic life offers a veil of legitimacy to criminal organizations. There have been a number of monks in a string of cases in recent years caught with methamphetamines, selling drugs,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.pattayaone.net/pattaya-news/62856/monks-accused-drug-dealing-caught-sattahip/ |title=Three Monks accused of drug dealing, caught in Sattahip |publisher=Pattayaone.net |date=2012-09-24 |accessdate=2014-04-12 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140413123836/http://www.pattayaone.net/pattaya-news/62856/monks-accused-drug-dealing-caught-sattahip/# |archive-date=2014-04-13 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref> prostitutes, pornography, and guns, including senior monks.<ref name="bkkpostsexmonastery">{{cite web|url=http://www.bangkokpost.com/blogs/index.php/2009/01/30/sex-in-the-monastery?blog=64 |archive-url=http://webarchive.loc.gov/all/20140819183300/http://www.bangkokpost.com/blogs/index.php/2009/01/30/sex-in-the-monastery?blog=64 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2014-08-19 |title=Sex in the monastery |work =Bangkok Post |date=2009-01-30 |accessdate=2014-04-12}}</ref>
One case involved two monks attempting to ditch speed pills at a police checkpoint.<ref name="bkkpostmonksarrested">{{cite web|url=http://www.bangkokpost.com/news/local/317428/monks-arrested-with-meth-pills |title=Monks arrested with meth pills |publisher=Bangkok Post |date=2012-10-17 |accessdate=2014-04-12}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.pattayaone.net/pattaya-news/51413/monks-caught-drugs-temple-sattahip-district/ |title=Two monks caught using drugs at Temple in Sattahip District |publisher=Pattayaone.net |date=2012-03-21 |accessdate=2014-04-12 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140413130925/http://www.pattayaone.net/pattaya-news/51413/monks-caught-drugs-temple-sattahip-district/# |archive-date=2014-04-13 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref> Another case involved a senior monk who claimed he needed money to "refurbish his temple", yet used the money for drugs and sex.<ref name="globalpost"/> Murder by clergy has been reported increasingly.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Thompson|first1=Geoff|title=Scandals follow Thailand's monks|url=http://downthecrookedpath-meditation-gurus.blogspot.com/2011/11/scandals-follow-thailands-monks.html|accessdate=7 Mar 2015|work=Down the Crooked Path|date=2011-11-05|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141224234459/http://downthecrookedpath-meditation-gurus.blogspot.com/2011/11/scandals-follow-thailands-monks.html|archive-date=2014-12-24|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref> There was even a case of Thai monks killing each other in the United States.<ref>{{cite web|author=Katherine Sayre |work= The Times-Picayune |url=http://blog.al.com/live/2012/05/buddhist_monk_accused_of_beati.html |title=Buddhist monk accused of beating fellow monk to death at Grand Bay temple|date=2012-05-12|accessdate=2014-04-12}}</ref> In addition, sexual assaults committed by Thai monks are not uncommon.{{CN|date=March 2017}} There is widespread sexual assault of male novices in temples, and of ''mae chi'' (Buddhist nuns) and lay women.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Murdoch|first1=Lindsay|title=Jet-setting Buddhist monk at centre of scandal|url=http://www.stuff.co.nz/world/asia/9082972/Jet-setting-Buddhist-monk-at-centre-of-scandal|website=stuff.co.nz|accessdate=3 April 2016}}</ref>
==Deaths of foreigners== A number of high-profile Westerners have died in Bangkok hotels including Hollywood actor [[David Carradine]], The director of [[Tata Motors]], [[Karl Slym]], (British), and American businesswoman [[Wendy Albano]].<ref name="asiancorrespondentstaff">{{cite web|url=http://asiancorrespondent.com/119002/tata-karl-slym-bangkok-hotel-deaths/|title=Tata boss 'suicide' becomes latest high-profile Bangkok hotel death|work=asiancorrespondent.com}}</ref> Although there have been crimes, Thai authorities have also had success in apprehending suspects such as in the case of two murdered backpackers and with the Albano murder.<ref name="thailandinthenews.com">[http://www.thailandinthenews.com/2015/12/two-burmese-myanmar-workers-sentenced-samui.html]{{unreliable source|date=November 2018}}</ref>
David Miller and Hannah Witheridge, a backpacking couple from England, were murdered on the island of [[Ko Tao]] in 2014. In December 2015 the suspected killers were found guilty.<ref name="thailandinthenews.com"/> They face execution by lethal injection.<ref name=thai>{{cite web| url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2015/jul/08/hannah-witheridge-david-millers-families-thailand-murder-trial|title=Families of British backpackers in Thailand for murder trial|work=the Guardian}}{{failed verification|date=November 2018}}</ref>
In 2013 an American expat was chopped to death by a Bangkok cabbie with a sword.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.richardbarrow.com/2013/07/taxi-driver-stabs-to-death-a-foreigner-in-bangkok/|title=Taxi Driver Hacks to Death a Foreigner in Bangkok|work=Richard Barrow in Thailand}}{{unreliable source|date=November 2018}}</ref> Murders are frequent enough that one writer produced a book called ''How Not To Get Murdered In Thailand''<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.newswire.com/press-release/thailand-murder-suspects-innocent-claims-how-not-to-get|title=Thailand Murder Suspects Innocent Claims How Not To Get Murdered In Thailand Author Andrew Gardner|work=newswire.com}}</ref> The author mentions the case of the murdered American Troy Pilkington and noted the contrasting dangers of both taxi cabs and public transportation.<ref name=mur>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=iwcOCQAAQBAJ&pg=PT10&lpg=PT10&dq=murdered+in+bangkok&source=bl&ots=ZqasiHAGYv&sig=pwsdLa_-79yYmElXqEb0ldR54S0&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CDUQ6AEwAzgUahUKEwjGgdzghJ_HAhVHJh4KHa4JAEI#v=onepage&q=wendy&f=false|title=How Not To Get Murdered In Thailand|work=google.com}}</ref> One of the issues with cabbies is their alleged drug use and abuse at the hands of Chinese organized crime network which often charge them high fee to operate in the city.<ref name=mur/> The cabbies are typically poor farmers trying to earn money for their rural families.<ref name=mur/> Whatever the reasons for their demise, indeed many of the deaths are confusing or have unclear causes, Thailand has remained popular for adventures.<ref name=christina>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/jan/22/british-backpacker-dead-thai-island-tourists|title=British backpacker found dead on same Thai island British pair were murdered|author=Amelia Hill|work=the Guardian}}</ref> One young Brit, Christina Annesley, was found dead on Thai's Ko Tao.<ref name=christina/> Musicians at a Thailand bar stabbed an American businessman to death in front of his son, there to celebrate his birthday with his family.<ref name="fox4news.com">[http://www.fox4news.com/story/22979925/dallas-business-man-killed-by-musician-in-thailand-bar Dallas businessman killed by musician in Thailand bar]{{Dead link|date=November 2015}}</ref> Thai police arrested three musicians for the crime.<ref name="fox4news.com"/>
The Thai government has worked with other countries to manage crime and, for example, has a prisoner exchange agreement with Australia.<ref>[http://www.theage.com.au/news/World/Asian-jails-not-very-good-Downer/2005/04/22/1114028529767.html Asian jails not very good: Downer], The Age, 22 April 2005</ref> In the case of Wendy Albano, India, Thailand, and the United States all worked together to find the primary suspect hiding in India.<ref name="CRT-20120314">{{cite news|title=Clinton's Help Sought in Thailand Murder|url=http://www.chiangraitimes.com/clintons-help-sought-in-thailand-murder.html|accessdate=8 August 2016|work=Chiang Rai Times|date=14 March 2012}}</ref> In that case that the help then U.S. Secretary of State Hillary Clinton and a U.S. senator was involved.<ref name="CRT-20120314" /> This was in part due to difficulty in apprehending a suspect, that had fled to a different country (and thus out of the jurisdiction of a single country).<ref name="CRT-20120314" />
===The case of Wendy Albano and foreigners on foreigners crime=== [[Wendy Albano]] was an American businesswoman murdered in 2012 in a hotel room in Thailand.<ref name=thaiw>[http://www.tampabay.com/news/publicsafety/crime/report-indian-police-make-arrest-in-2012-murder-of-south-tampa-designer/2200082 Police in India arrest suspect in 2012 murder of South Tampa designer]</ref> Authorities in the U.S. got in touch with the U.S. State department eventually leading to the arrest of a suspect hiding in India years later.<ref name=thaiw/> The chief suspect was an Indian business associate who fled to India after her death.<ref name=bk>[http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2102052/Wendy-Albano-dead-Florida-socialite-murdered-Bangkok-hotel-Indian-boyfriend.html Socialite murdered]{{unreliable source|date=November 2018}}</ref> One of the key pieces of evidence that made him a suspect was their known business relationship and video surveillance from the hotel.<ref name=thaiw/> U.S. Sen. [[Bill Nelson (politician)|Bill Nelson]] asked then secretary of State [[Hillary Clinton]] to help with the case.<ref name="Nelson-2012">{{cite web|title=U.S. senator seeks Clinton's help in case of Tampa woman murdered in Bangkok hotel|url=https://www.billnelson.senate.gov/newsroom/press-releases/us-senator-seeks-clinton-s-help-in-case-of-tampa-woman-murdered-in-bangkok|website=Bill Nelson Florida|accessdate=8 August 2016|date=2012-03-12|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160821175017/https://www.billnelson.senate.gov/newsroom/press-releases/us-senator-seeks-clinton-s-help-in-case-of-tampa-woman-murdered-in-bangkok#|archive-date=2016-08-21|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref> Senator Nelson took steps to help India and Thailand work together to solve the crime.<ref name="Nelson-2012" /> The case made headlines in the United States and India, especially due to the involvement of a U.S. Senator and request for help from then Secretary of State Clinton.<ref name="CRT-20120314" />
This is the case where foreigners commit crimes against other foreigners in Thailand, in Albano's case the chief suspect was an Indian man who fled Thailand but was eventually captured in India with the help of the Indian law enforcement.<ref name="asiancorrespondentstaff"/>

Unknown number of Mexicans of Czech descent |popplace = [[Mexico City]] |langs = [[Mexican Spanish]]{{·}}[[Czech language|Czech]] |rels = [[Roman Catholicism]] |related = [[Czech diaspora]] }} {{Czechs}} '''Czech Mexicans''' ({{lang-es|checo-mexicanos{{cite web|last1=Valverde|first1=Freddy|title=La Asociación Tomáš Garrigue Masaryk, fomenta las relaciones culturales entre mexicanos y checos|url=http://www.radio.cz/es/rubrica/panorama/la-asociacion-tomas-garrigue-masaryk-fomenta-las-relaciones-culturales-entre-mexicanos-y-checos|publisher=[[Radio Prague]]|accessdate=11 February 2016}}}}) are citizens of Mexico who are of [[Czechs|Czech descent]]. Czechs originate from the [[Czech lands]], a term which refers to the majority of the traditional [[lands of the Bohemian Crown]], namely [[Bohemia]], [[Moravia]] and [[Czech Silesia]]. These lands of have been governed by a variety of states, including the [[Kingdom of Bohemia]], a crown land of the [[Austrian Empire]], the [[Czechoslovakia|Czechoslovak Republic]], and, now, the [[Czech Republic]]. ==History== {{Expand section|date=February 2016}} During the colonial era, several Bohemian [[Jesuit]] missionaries were involved in the evangelization of Mexico. The Czech community in Mexico has been a discrete community, most of them arrived to the country as refugees escaping from World Wars. The Czech community of Mexico City frequently meets for celebrations at the statue of [[Tomáš Garrigue Masaryk]] located on [[Avenida Presidente Masaryk]]. ==Cultural organizations== * [[Asociación Tomáš Garrigue Masaryk]] ==Notable individuals== * [[Angélica Aragón|Angélica Espinoza Stransky]], actress * [[Juan de Esteyneffer]], Jesuit missionary * [[Wenceslaus Linck]], Jesuit missionary * [[Rubén Marshall Tikalova]], editorial director * [[Miroslava Stern|Miroslava]], actress of the [[Golden Age of Mexican cinema]] * [[Sylvia Schmelkes]], sociologist * [[Zaneta Seirelova]], actress and model * [[Sasha Sokol]], actress and singer ==See also== * [[Czech Republic–Mexico relations]] * [[Norteño (music)]], influenced by Central European immigrants == References == {{reflist}} ==Further reading== * Odložilík, Otakar "Czech Missionaries in New Spain", ''The Hispanic American Historical Review'', Vol. 25, No. 4 (Nov., 1945), pp. 428-454 * Polzer, Charles W. {{Use dmy dates|date=May 2017}} {{other uses|Daniel Hennessey (disambiguation)}} {{notability|date=April 2017}} {{Infobox person | name = Daniel Hennessey | image = | alt = | caption = | birth_name = Daniel Hennessey | birth_date = {{birth date and age|df=yes|1968|01|15}} | birth_place = [[Fall River, Massachusetts]], [[United States]] | death_date = | death_place = | nationality = American | other_names = Lt Dan Hennessey
DJ Danimal | occupation = Announcer | years_active = | known_for = "Would Somebody, Somewhere, Make Some Noise!" Catchphrase | notable_works = }} '''Daniel Hennessey''' (born 15 January 1968, [[Fall River, Massachusetts]], United States) also known as Lt Dan, is a New Zealand [[ring announcer]] for boxing, kickboxing and other combat sports. He is known for his catchphrase, "Would Somebody, Somewhere, Make Some Noise!". ==Early life== Hennessey attended [[Worcester State College]]. After college he joined the [[United States Marine Corps]] in 1991, being in [[Gulf War|operations DesertShield/Storm]]. Earlier, while a member of the U.S. Marine Reserves he had participated in a major Christmas Season 1989 fundraiser for the Vietnam Veterans Association of Cape Cod ( also known as The Nam Vets of Cape Cod) by standing at attention for 24-straight hours outside Hyannis radio station WPXC-FM. During the promotion he was only permitted a 5-minute break every two hours. It raised several thousand dollars for the worthy organization and made Hennessey a regular "honorary member" of the WPXC airstaff for several years to come. He went on to serve in the first Persian Gulf War. {{cite web|url=https://newzealandfighter.co.nz/home/would-somebody-somewhere-make-some-noise|title=Would somebody, Somewhere, Make some Noise|publisher=NZ Fighter |date= |accessdate=12 April 2017}} He left the Marine Corp in 1993 and moved to [[New Zealand]] in 1998 to be a Club DJ. In the DJ scene he was well known for his stage name as DJ Danimal. During his DJ time, he was on [[Radio Hauraki]] and Max TV between 2000 and 2002.{{cite web|url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/lifestyle/news/article.cfm?c_id=6&objectid=231916|title=This week|publisher=NZ Herald |date= |accessdate=12 April 2017}} ==Announcing and commentating== Hennessey started working at Sky TV in New Zealand in 2003 as a commentator, mainly focusing on basketball for the NZNBL.{{cite web|url=http://davelintott.photoshelter.com/image/I0000NXxw.hlEkXE|title=Photo of Dan Hennessey and Elizabeth Cambage|publisher= |date= |accessdate=12 April 2017}}{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=OQhCEpSi8NA|title=NZ Basketball NBL Highlight Reel 2006 !! Dan Hennessey Commentary|publisher=Youtube |date= |accessdate=12 April 2017}} The biggest accomplishment of his commentating career was head commentating for the FIBA Under 19's world champ in 2012. Hennessey finished with the doing stats for the Breakers in their 2016 season.{{cite web|url=http://websites.sportstg.com/assoc_page.cgi?c=1-3990-0-0-0&sID=81885&articleID=9738813&news_task=DETAIL|title=INTERNATIONALS LIVE ON SKY TV|publisher=Basketball Hawkes Bay |date= |accessdate=12 April 2017}} Hennessey started ring announcing at a kickboxing show called Kings of Oceania. He made a big break in his career by announcing the 2006 World Grand Prix K1. A few years later, he announced the event that will defined his career where he announced Duco Events [[David Tua]] vs [[Shane Cameron]] in 2009, which at the time the biggest PPV buy in New Zealand History.{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=QiYRAYKxhb4|title=David Tua vs Shane Cameron|publisher=Youtube |date= |accessdate=12 April 2017}} Hennessey went on to announce David Tua's last four fights of his career. Hennessey became the main announcer for Duco Event's,{{cite web|url=http://photosportnz.photoshelter.com/image/I0000XN.7pohqTrQ|title=Boxing – KFC Fight For Life, Hamilton, 6 December 2014|publisher=Photo Sports NZ |date= |accessdate=12 April 2017}} [[King in the Ring]],{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=MM0E74zuorE|title=King in the Ring Trans Tasman 8 Man Final: Israel Adesanya vs Pati Afoa|publisher=Youtube |date= |accessdate=12 April 2017}} most of [[Joseph Parker (boxer)|Joseph Parker]] boxing bouts and [[Joseph Parker vs. Andy Ruiz]].{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vE8VAOgZZPI|title=Joseph Parker Vs Andy Ruiz "WBO Heavyweight Title Fight"|publisher=Youtube |date= |accessdate=12 April 2017}} Hennessey announced Parker's first World title defense and the non televised bouts of [[Manny Pacquiao vs. Jeff Horn]]. Hennessey also announces local events including [[Benjamin Thomas Watt]] only boxing event,{{cite web|url=http://auckland.scoop.co.nz/2016/07/btw-announces-nz-title/|title=BTW Announces NZ Title|publisher=Scoop |date= |accessdate=12 April 2017}} [[Sam Rapira (boxer)|Sam Rapira]] New Plymouth, Lance Bryant in Manawatu{{cite web|url=http://www.stuff.co.nz/manawatu-standard/sport/80461338/Bryant-will-have-to-go-the-extra-distance-at-Pahiatua-Fight-Night|title=Bryant will have to go the extra distance at Pahiatua Fight Night|publisher=Stuff.co.nz |date= |accessdate=12 April 2017}}{{cite web|url=http://www.stuff.co.nz/manawatu-standard/sport/90410752/Thursday-night-lights-for-Battle-of-the-Belts-boxing-event|title=Thursday night lights for Battle of the Belts boxing event|publisher=Stuff.co.nz |date= |accessdate=12 April 2017}} and many more boxing events. His first world title he announced was Kali Reis vs Maricela Cornejo for the WBC World female middleweight title in April 2016 at [[The Trusts Arena]].{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=z-PX58ob2-o&t=1s|title=Maricela Cornejo vs Kali KO Reis WBC WORLD TITLE MIDDLEWEIGHT|publisher=Youtube |date= |accessdate=12 April 2017}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[https://www.bigmouthvoices.com/voices/lt-dan-hennessey Big Mouth Voices Profile] *[http://boxrec.com/media/index.php/Daniel_Hennessey Boxrec Profile] {{DEFAULTSORT:Hennessey, Daniel}} [[Category:1968 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Mixed martial arts announcers]] [[Category:Boxing people]] [[Category:Public address announcers]]

The demographic features of [[Brunei]] include [[population density]], [[Ethnic group|ethnicity]], education level, health of the populace, economic status, religious affiliations and other aspects of the population. Like neighbouring countries, [[Brunei]] is a [[Malays (ethnic group)|Malay]]-dominated country. Many cultural and linguistic differences make Brunei Malays distinct from the larger Malay populations in nearby [[Malaysia]] and [[Indonesia]], even though they are ethnically related and share the [[Islam|Muslim]] religion.
Brunei has a hereditary nobility with the title Pengiran these are, more often than not, related to the Sultan by blood. The Sultan can award to commoners the title [[Pehin]], the equivalent of a [[life peerage]] awarded in the [[United Kingdom]]. The Sultan also can award his subjects the [[Malay titles|Dato]], the equivalent of a [[knighthood]] in the United Kingdom, and Datin, the equivalent of a damehood.
Bruneians adhere to the practice of using complete full names with all titles, including the title [[Hajji|Haji]] (for men) or Hajjah (for women) for those who have made the Haj pilgrimage to Mecca. Many Brunei Malay women wear the [[tudong]], a traditional head covering. Men wear the [[songkok]], a traditional Malay cap. Men who have completed the Haj wear a white songkok.
The requirements to attain Brunei citizenship include passing tests in Malay culture, customs and [[Malay language|language]]. Stateless permanent residents of Brunei are given International Certificates of Identity, which allow them to travel overseas. The majority of Brunei's Chinese are permanent residents, and many are stateless.
[[Petroleum]] wealth allows the Brunei Government to provide the population with one of [[Asia]]'s finest [[health care]] systems. The [[Brunei Medical and Health Department]] introduced the region's first government "flying doctor service" in early 1965. [[Malaria]] has been eradicated, and [[cholera]] is virtually nonexistent. There are three general hospitals--in Bandar Seri Begawan, Tutong, and Kuala Belait--and there are numerous health clinics throughout the country.
[[Education]] starts with [[preschool]], followed by 6 years of [[primary education]] and up to 6 years of [[secondary education]]. Nine years of education are mandatory. Most of Brunei's [[college]] students attend [[university|universities]] and other institutions abroad, but approximately 2,542 study at the [[University of Brunei Darussalam]]. Opened in 1985, the university has a faculty of over 300 instructors and is located on a sprawling campus at [[Tungku]], overlooking the [[South China Sea]].
The official language is [[Malay language|Malay]], but [[English language|English]] is widely understood and used in business. Other languages spoken are several [[Chinese language|Chinese]] dialects, [[Iban language|Iban]], and a number of native dialects. [[Islam]] is the official religion, but religious freedom is guaranteed under the constitution.

'''Emigration from Mexico''' is a migratory phenomenon that has been taking place in [[Mexico]] since the early 20th century.
==Overview== [[Emigration]] from Mexico began timidly about a century ago, but experienced a significant increase since the 1960s. The emigration phenomenon, in the case of Mexico is diverse and varied through the country. This is due to the economic situation that applies mainly to poorer people, who seek better job opportunities in other countries. More than 11% of Mexico’s native population lives abroad, making it the country with the most emigrants in the world. 98% of all Mexican emigrants reside in the United States, which are more than 12 million (documented and undocumented) migrants. Estimates on the amount of Mexican emigrants of indigenous origin in the U.S. range between 50% and 90% of the entire emigrant population. There are no official numbers on the amount of indigenous Mexican migrants, as U.S. censuses do not cover their specific ethnic origin. Recent reports by the [[Pew Research Center]] (February 2012) show that the current migratory influx from Mexico to the U.S. is just below a net zero, as more Mexicans leave the U.S. Economic problems are, overall, the little stability of [[Mexican peso]] exchange rate compared to the [[United States dollar]]. That is the reason for many Mexicans to leave their country and look for better salaries in the [[United States]], so they can send dollars to their families in Mexico. This case, however, is mainly temporary. Many others chose to permanently reside there with their families.
==Destinations== Aside from the [[Mexican American|United States]], Mexican immigrants have settled in [[Mexican Canadian|Canada]], [[Mexican immigration to Spain|Spain]], [[Mexicans in Germany|Germany]], [[Italy]], the [[Mexicans in the United Kingdom|United Kingdom]], [[France]], [[Japan]] and other countries. A large Mexican immigrant population also exists in Central and South American countries as [[Mexicans in Guatemala|Guatemala]], [[Mexicans in Costa Rica|Costa Rica]], [[Mexicans in Cuba|Cuba]], [[Brazil]], [[Colombia]] and [[Chile]]. Mexican Mennonites settled in [[Bolivia]], [[Argentina]] and [[Paraguay]]. There have been cases of Mexicans working and residing in [[Ukraine]] and [[Saudi Arabia]] where they are employed as construction and oil labor contractors. Under "Aliyah", or the immigration of Jews of the Diaspora to Israel, an unspecified number of Mexican Jews have immigrated to Israel. In recent years Mexican business and enigineering professionals have settled in African countries like [[Kenya]], [[Nigeria]] and [[South Africa]].
Canada has a program that hires Mexican agricultural workers on a temporary basis. Many countries allow Mexicans opportunities in areas like science research, to study at colleges and universities, and through other cultural exchanges. The mass departure of artists, scientists, actors and more has led to a Mexican [[brain drain]]. However, recent years have shown an uptick in immigration to Mexico.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/09/22/world/americas/for-migrants-new-land-of-opportunity-is-mexico.html|title=For Migrants, New Land of Opportunity Is Mexico|first=Damien|last=Cave|date=21 September 2013|publisher=|via=NYTimes.com}}</ref>
==Type of people and impact on Mexican society== Generally, the people who tend to leave Mexico to the United States are from lower-class backgrounds and of [[Mestizos in Mexico|mestizo]]{{Dubious|date=October 2015}} or [[Indigenous peoples of Mexico|indigenous]] ancestries. They primarily come from the following nine [[List of states of Mexico|states]]: [[Zacatecas]], [[Guanajuato]], [[Michoacán]], [[Oaxaca]], [[Guerrero]], [[San Luis Potosí]], [[Hidalgo (state)|Hidalgo]], [[Chiapas]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.inegi.gob.mx/prod_serv/contenidos/espanol/bvinegi/productos/censos/poblacion/2010/princi_result/cpv2010_principales_resultadosIV.pdf|title=Migración internacional en el quinquenio 2005-2010 (International Migration 2005-2010)|website=inegi.gob.mx}}</ref> and [[Sinaloa]]. In these states it is not uncommon to see towns where men are absent, and are supposed to be working in the [[United States]]. While the women take care of their children, husbands [[Remittances from the United States|send money (dollars) to their families]] in Mexico. This money, sent by Mexican workers abroad to their country, is called ''[[Remittance|remesas]]'' in Spanish, and the amount of it have become the second income that Mexico receives from other countries. The first one is oil sales.
On the other hand, people from the educated middle-upper class, are usually [[Criollo people|criollo]]{{Dubious|date=October 2015}} or other [[Mexicans of European descent]] and some of [[castizo]]{{Dubious|date=October 2015}} descent, they emigrate to the [[United States]], but also many emigrate to Canada and European countries; they're usually employed by companies, universities, or many of them start their own businesses abroad.
Traditionally, richer people with overwhelming income used to live in Mexico, but recent economic opportunities and advantages with international treaties, harassing, and threatening insecurity have made them leave the country.
==Causes and origins== Following the [[Mexican–American War]] which was concluded by the [[Treaty of Guadalupe Hidalgo]] in 1848, and later, the [[Gadsden Purchase]] in 1853, approximately 300,000 Mexican nationals found themselves living within the [[United States]]. Throughout the rest of the 19th century early 20th century, Mexican migration was not subject to any restrictions, and Mexicans were free to move across the border, and often did so, typically in order for them to work in professions such as the construction of the railway system, or as seasonal [[agricultural]] laborers. From 1910 to 1920, the political violence and societal chaos caused by the [[Mexican Revolution]] also played a role in increasing migration northwards. Economic inequality, rural poverty, significantly lower wages, and better opportunities have also played a role throughout the 20th century as factors pulling Mexicans to migrate to the US.
The immigration laws of the United States such as [[Emergency Quota Act]] generally allowed exemptions for Mexico, while being more restrictive to citizens of the [[Eastern Hemisphere]].<ref name=bean/> Mexicans received special allowances under United States immigration law due to the importance of Mexican labor in the United States [[economy]]. One example of these allowances is the [[Immigration Act of 1917]]. Under this act, all potential immigrants would have to pass a [[literacy test]] and pay a head tax.{{Citation needed|date=November 2011}} At the request of growers in the southwest who depended on farm labor from Mexico, the [[United States Secretary of Labor|Secretary of Labor]] waived those requirements for Mexican immigrants.<ref name=bean/> The groups interested in the availability of inexpensive labor ensured that the immigration laws in place throughout the early 20th century did not adversely affect the movement of Mexican migrants, in spite of calls on the part of some of the southern states’ [[congressmen]] to put an end to the open border policies.{{Citation needed|date=June 2013}}
==Effects of governmental policies on Mexican immigration in the U.S.==
===Restrictive regulations=== [[File:Border Wall at Tijuana and San Diego Border.jpg|thumb|[[:en:Mexico–United States barrier|Mexico–United States barrier]] at the border of [[:en:Tijuana|Tijuana, Mexico]] and [[:en:San Diego|San Diego, USA]]. The crosses represent migrants who died in the crossing attempt. Some identified, some not. Surveillance tower in the background.]] The [[Great Depression|economic crisis of 1929]] brought an abrupt end to the special allowances that had been allowed for Mexican immigrants.<ref>Lorey, David E. The U.S.-Mexican Border in the Twentieth Century. Wilmington, Scholarly Resources, Inc.: 1999 {{ISBN|0842027564}}.</ref> With the beginning of the Great Depression, the worldwide economic slowdown and the desperate search for jobs within the United States of America, [[Opposition to immigration|anti-immigration sentiment]] rose. Thousands of Mexicans were forced back across the border and barriers to future immigrants were constructed. From 1929 to 1931, legal Mexican immigration entries fell by 95%, and in the next ten years as many as 400,000 Mexican citizens were [[repatriated]].<ref name=bean/>
===More admissive regulations=== The limitations on Mexican immigration lasted until the beginning of [[World War II]], when the United States found itself short of labor. In 1942 the United States and Mexico instituted the [[Bracero program]]. Under this arrangement, millions of Mexican laborers were contracted to complete agricultural work in the United States. While under contract they were given housing and received a [[minimum wage]] of thirty cents an hour. The program was intended to provide the United States with ''temporary'' workers while many working-aged men were away at war. In order to ensure that braceros did not stay in the United States, their wives and families were not allowed to accompany them in the U.S. Additionally, 10% of each worker’s wage was withheld to be given back upon the worker’s return to Mexico but few U.S. employers complied.
The Bracero Program allowed [[agribusiness]] access to a large pool of labor that had virtually no civil rights, and no recourse to address growing injustices. This inequity was seen in poor working conditions and the decrease in agricultural wages, which during the 1950s, actually dropped below the levels they were at during World War II.{{Citation needed|date=November 2011}} As the war ended, few returning soldiers returned to the jobs that the braceros were holding, and instead, they moved on to more industrial areas and reinforced the belief that immigrants take on the jobs that Americans would not be willing to do.
The [[Politics of Mexico|Mexican government's]] participation and oversight of the treatment of their workers in this program declined over the years, despite remittances from the program that made up a large part of its domestic economy. The United States began encouraging braceros to cross into Mexico then return illegally to the United States. {{Citation needed|date=November 2011}} Upon return they could become legal citizens, and this eliminated any program contracts as well as the ability of the [[Mexican government]] to intervene in any future labor relations. In addition to this practice of creating legal citizens of former braceros, thousands of illegal immigrants were crossing the border in search of the opportunity promised by the idea of steady employment and eventual prosperity of the Bracero Program.
==A return to a more closed border== In response to the growing number of Mexicans entering illegally, the United States government implemented [[Operation Wetback]] in 1954. Under the direction of the [[Immigration and Naturalization Service]] (INS), the [[United States Border Patrol|Border Patrol]] began deporting Mexicans who were in the United States illegally, and up to one million Mexicans were deported. Operation Wetback ended not long after its launch, due to the complaints regarding the violence involved in the deportations, and the fact that in many cases children of immigrants who were United States citizens were deported with their parents.<ref>Public Broadcasting Services [https://www.pbs.org/kpbs/theborder/history/index.html “The Border History”].</ref>
===Continuing migration=== Although the Bracero Program ended in 1964, the migration of Mexican workers did not. The [[Immigration and Nationality Act of 1952]] which had put limits on the total number of visas granted, was [[Immigration and Nationality Act of 1965|amended in 1965]] following the termination of the Bracero Program. These amendments put an end to the quota system, and instead, created a total number of visas allowed to the Western Hemisphere. Exceptions to that total number were granted to spouses, minors and parents of United States citizens. However, the total allotment of 120,000 in 1965 still was not enough to address the demand for visas from Mexico. By 1976, there was a two-year waiting period for any eligible applicant from the Western Hemisphere before they could receive a visa.<ref name=bean>Bean, Frank D. et al (eds). At the Crossroads: Mexico and U.S. Immigration Policy. Lanham, Rowman & Littlefield Publishers, Inc.: 1997 {{ISBN|0847683923}}.</ref>
===Displaced workers in northern Mexico=== A contributing factor to the persistently high numbers of migrants from Mexico was the creation of the [[Border Industrialization Program]] in 1965. The termination of the Bracero Program in 1964 had led to both a shortage of workers willing to work for lower wages in the United States, and a high population of displaced workers at the northern Mexico border. The result of this imbalance in the supply and demand of labor in the two countries in turn led the creation of this new agreement that allowed the construction of foreign-owned factories in northern Mexico. These factories are referred to as [[maquiladoras]] or maquilas, and provided both Mexico and the United States with a number of benefits. The factories provided Mexico with a way to increase its manufactured exports to the United States, and in return, the United States received tax benefits for placing its factories within Mexico. For example, the equipment imported into Mexico to be used in the factories was not subject to import taxes, and the final product was only taxed on the value that was added at the factory, rather than the entirety of the item.<ref>Morales, Gerard et al. [http://www.dol.gov/ilab/media/reports/nao/maquilad.htm#viiits “An Overview of the Maquiladora Program”]. United States Department of Labor. 1994.</ref>
The creation of the maquilas program provided jobs to the displaced Bracero Program workers and allowed the United States to continue to use labor from Mexico, which was less expensive than labor in the United States. The popularity of this program is evident in the incredible increase in the number of maquilas in operation: in 1967 there were 57 maquiladoras operating in Mexico; less than ten years later in 1976, that number had increased to 552. The rise in the number of available jobs in the region led to an extreme swell in the population of the border towns. The maquiladora industry employed 4000 people in 1967, and by 1981 that amount grew to more than 130,000.<ref>Seligson, Mitchell A. & Edward J. Williams. Maquiladoras and Migration: Workers in the Mexico – United States Border Industrialization Program. Austin, University of Texas Press: 1981, {{ISBN|0292750722}}.</ref> The maquilas drew the population north to the border in search of employment opportunities, but in many cases the northward pull did not stop there. The proximity of the United States with its markedly higher standard of living continued to pull the people who had migrated to border region even farther north, and led to higher numbers of migrants crossing the [[United States – Mexico border]].
Amendments to the [[Immigration and Nationality Act of 1965|Immigration and Nationality Act]] continued throughout the 1970s. In 1976 the United State Congress imposed a limit of 20,000 visas per country per year in the Western Hemisphere. At that time Mexico was exceeding that amount by approximately 40,000. In 1978 a new amendment was put in place that enacted a worldwide immigration policy, allowing 290,000 visas per year total, with no limitations per country.
The end of the Bracero Program combined with restrictions put on the number of visas allowed by the United States greatly increased the levels of illegal migration from Mexico.<ref name=bean/> As a response, in 1986 the United States enacted the [[Immigration Reform and Control Act]] (IRCA). Under this act, all undocumented migrants living in the United States as of January 1, 1982, as well as those who had labored in the seasonal agriculture work for at least ninety days during the previous years were granted legal residence. IRCA also made it possible to impose civil and criminal penalties on any employer who knowingly hired undocumented workers. Although a legalization of current undocumented workers, coupled with the increase in penalties suffered by employers who employed future undocumented workers was meant to decrease the total number of undocumented migrants in the United States, the actions did not produce the desired effect; as is evidenced by the number of apprehensions achieved through border patrolling.
==Recent trend reversal in migration Mexico-U.S.== Still today, Mexico is the country with the most emigrants in the world, but during the last few years, migratory patterns from Mexico to the United States have changed. A report by the [[Pew Research Center]] (February 2012) has shown that for the first time in 60 years, migration trends have reversed, as more Mexicans leave the U.S. than enter it.
===Reasons for trend reversal=== Several major factors seem to contribute to a general sense among Mexican migrants that there is less profit and more danger to migrate to the U.S., leading many of them to decide that it is better to leave the U.S. or stay in Mexico:<ref name=r1>Nájar, A. (2012-03-09). [http://www.bbc.co.uk/mundo/noticias/2012/03/120309_migracion_mexico_eeuu_reversa_an.shtml Migración mexicana en EE.UU.: el flujo ahora va en sentido contrario]. BBC</ref> *The decline of fertility in Mexico has resulted in proportionally fewer young people, and thus lower migration to the U.S.<ref>What Mexican immigration problem? Richard Miles USA Today Jan 2015 https://www.usatoday.com/story/opinion/2015/01/03/mexican-immigration-richard-miles/21056155/</ref> *The 2008–2012 [[global financial crisis|economic crisis of 2008]] has led to a decline of work opportunities in the U.S., meaning that many immigrants who came to the U.S. for work couldn't find any. Access to social security, healthcare and education has also become more difficult. *The economic situation in Mexico has become better, ensuring better access to healthcare, education, and jobs. This reduces the incentive for Mexicans to leave the country. *Since 2010, U.S. legislation on illegal immigration has been reinforced, as several American states criminalized illegal immigration. Deportations under the Obama administration have reached record numbers. *During the last few years, violence associated with drug cartels and organized crime has been on the rise in Northern Mexico, making the routes for passing the border more dangerous. *Mexicans and Americans Thinking Together (MATT) conducted 600 in-depth, in person interviews of migrants who returned to the Mexican state of Jalisco, that found family reasons and nostalgia are the primary cited reasons for return migration Mexico. The research also found that of the interviewed migrants who moved back to Mexico, only about 11% were forced to leave the United States due to being deported. 75% of the respondents cited that their reasons for return migration were self-motivated.<ref>Mexicans and Americans Thinking Together (MATT)Quantitative Research Study Preliminary Findings and Insights The US/Mexico Cycle End of an Era http://www.matt.org/uploads/2/4/9/3/24932918/returnmigration_top_line_www.pdf Dec 2013</ref>
===Developments in Mexico=== Mexican source communities, mostly indigenous villages, are most often poor and rely heavily on the emigration of a part of their members and the remittances they send back to survive economically. Emigration can function as an escape valve to alleviate economical pressure, as it is a source of income and opens up work opportunities in villages of origin.<ref name=r2/> The return of many migrants now thus causes great stress on these communities, who are heading for economic crisis, as important sources of income fall away and more people become unemployed as there is less work available. The states most affected by this phenomenon try to take action to help those who come back, but the full economic impact of the return of migrants is still to come.<ref name=r1/>
Since emigrants are coming back to their mostly poor home communities, sending them into economic crisis, another migration phenomenon is accelerating: internal migration. The lack of work opportunities in small villages drives people to migrate to large cities, rather than to the U.S.. With 78% of the Mexican population living in urban zones, slums are growing fast. Urban violence and crime, stunted growth, malnutrition, poor elementary education, poor hygiene and sanitation are just some of the implications of life in urban slums. According to [[UNICEF]], urban migration has badly worsened the reach of social schemes of health and nutrition.<ref>UNICEF, 2012. The State of the World’s Children 2012, Executive Summary: Children in an Urban World. New York: United Nations Children’s Fund.</ref>
Among communities of origin, there is a widespread ambivalence towards migrants, as the money they send back is welcome, but there is resentment against the cultural changes that they bring with them when they come back. Returning migrants are blamed for bringing with them drug use, sexually transmitted diseases, and antisocial behavior. They are held responsible for the abandonment of the traditional indigenous way of life as they bring back western cultural habits and material culture. The return of migrants to Mexico thus has important cultural repercussions and changes the face of their home communities forever.<ref name=r2>Fitzgerald, D., 2009. A Nation of Emigrants: How Mexico manages its Migration. Berkeley and Los Angeles: University of California Press {{ISBN|0520257057}}.</ref>
===Developments in the U.S.=== In the U.S., Hispanics account for 54% of the day labor workforce{{dubious|date=November 2015}} and there is a large market for cheap day-laborers. This sector constitutes a non-negligible part of the U.S. economy. With the current migration trends, within a few years, Mexico will not be able to cover current demand for Mexican labor of its neighbor anymore. Migration from El Salvador, Guatemala, and Honduras to the U.S. is rising, as their migrants begin to replace Mexican workers. It is however unclear whether other [[Hispanic America]]n countries follow these trends, and it is unsure whether the gap left by returning Mexican will be filled by such migrants. Experts say the consequences for the U.S. economy may be important.<ref name=r1/>
Since 2010, deportations of illegal immigrants have increased, as deportation procedures became more systematic and border controls were reinforced with police and military patrols. Several states, such as Arizona and Alabama, have passed laws that criminalize illegal migration. Proposed acts that offer easier paths to U.S. citizenship for immigrants, such as the DREAM-act, have been rejected.
